Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CI-ADDO-EN: Making Internet Routing Data Accessible To All

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: RouteViews is a system for systematically collecting data on the routes (the paths by which data gets from point A to point B) used by Internet traffic. It has played a critical role in the study of significant events, such as large scale outages, that have taken place in the Internet. The RouteViews data archives are the most widely used source of Internet routing data for the computer networking, network operations and network security communities. They are also increasingly being used in studies of network topological growth and network economics. However, access to the RouteViews data has been challenging to new users since the data is current structured as flat binary files with no simple interfaces for searching or accessing the data.

This project will design and implement database access to the RouteViews data, and will develop simple interfaces and tools for accessing the data. The resources used to acquire and store the data will also be expanded. The project will open up the use of routing data to a broader community including undergraduate education. It will work with the community to raise awareness about the potential uses of routing data in research and education, and will promote the use of the new access methods.

The project will expand routing data collection, will make it easier to access the collected data and will benefit networking research, network operations and network security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is the de-facto inter-domain routing protocol in the Internet. Studying BGP is of the highest importance in order to understand, improve, and deploy enhancements; develop solutions to route hijacks, and man-in-the-middle attacks; detect network outages and censorship; avoid paths through rogue nations; obey privacy laws, and much more. Solutions to these problems require a global, continuous BGP monitoring infrastructure. Built over the years by painstakingly forging relationships, RouteViews (RV) at the University of Oregon (UO) has been operating and maintaining the largest and longest-lived known BGP monitoring infrastructure that makes data freely available to researchers and industry. With 21 routing collectors located around the world at key locations such as London, Sydney, Singapore, São Paulo, Virginia, and Palo Alto, and about 550 active peering sessions including 189 IPv6 peers, the infrastructure has true global coverage. Over 200 different organizations share information with RV, including many of the largest ISPs in the world. The large number of IPv6 peers has been instrumental in monitoring the growth of IPv6.

RV continues to diligently maintain the collection infrastructure. Colorado State University (CSU) has implemented a new, lightweight collector based on the GO language and software developed at NTT (goBGPd). A lightweight collector is important to scale data collection. CSU has developed and maintains an HTTP-based archive that allows access to all current and historic BGP data in real-time. The work was presented at NANOG69. The archive has been in constant use by both researchers and industry. RV logged over 29M downloads from over 150 organizations in October 2017. CSU’s archive, a much younger service, logged over 800 unique IP addresses (excluding noise such as search engine bots) April - October 2017.

BGPMon and RV have been instrumental in enabling research in BGP routing and security. The infrastructure has been providing researchers with unfettered access to global routing data for almost two decades. Numerous papers have been written and many presentations at NANOG, APNIC, etc. used the data to show interesting properties of the Internet. Many projects base their existence on the data’s continued availability. Some recent examples include BGPStream, IODA and Internet ATLAS. Seminal papers such as Craig Labovitz’s paper on BGP instabilities would not be possible without this data.
